intro: Astragalus calvaryformis, commonly known as the rock milkvetch, is a flowering plant native to the arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a perennial herb that typically grows in rocky soils and crevices, showcasing its adaptability to harsh environments. The plant produces small, yellowish to reddish flowers in late spring to early summer, which are clustered in dense inflorescences. Its leaves are compound, consisting of several pairs of small, oval-shaped leaflets. Astragalus calvaryformis is valued for its ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing nectar for pollinators in its native habitat.
